title: Uncovering the Complex Nanoscale Architecture of Human Enamel and Insights in Its Nanoscale Mechanical Properties
content: As a major component of teeth, dental enamel has evolved to bear substantial mastication forces, withstand wear, and resist mechanical fatigue over decades of usage. Due to its combination of high mineral content (∼96 wt%) together with its complex three-dimensional (3D) hierarchical structure across length scales, enamel is the hardest tissue in the human body (∼2-6 GPa). Despite this remarkable hardness, loss and/or functional impairment of its structure with time still occurs, which has a significant impact on health and quality of life, in addition to the associated substantial costs to society.
